poem:
A Taste of Crowds

Menus flutter, London breathes—  
a thousand forks lifted,  
yet no one tongue  
tastes the same dish  
twice. The gods of eating  
divine amidst chatter  
and clinking glass,  
debate a futile quest—  
for every plate, a palette,  
every meal, a whisper  
of secret, undiscovered.  
Eat! Argue!  
The city's feast awaits!
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "I ate 3,000 meals for my ‘best of London restaurants’ list – and I hope you disagree with it | Jonathan Nunn Almost 24 years ago, a small British food magazine called Restaurant assembled an all-star panel – made up of Gordon Ramsay, John Torode, Aldo Zilli and 65 other food guys – to adjudicate on the world’s most stupid question: what is the best restaurant on the planet? It didn’t matter that no judge". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
